Tuesday, January 9, 1934

Let's Dodge The Issue
Modestly boasting himself as no more than an
undergraduate, a correspondent in our letter column
today asks why additional charges are made when
the Student Activities Fee is guaranteed to entitle
students to all activity functions without further
charge. The query is interesting, not because of possessing any originality but because it is one which
numerous simple-hearted lads have advanced with
varying degrees of temerity.
We don't know of anybody on the campus who
pretends that the plan is fair. The whole matter,
briefly, is this: creditors not paid last semester because of the bank closing raised such a holler when
activities fees were collected this year that they had to
be paid before we could go on with anything else.
This took over half of our money. Assuming that
activities are necessary and that the students want
them (pity THE NEWS-LETTER if they don't), the only
way that any operations were possible at all was to
disregard the principle of the thing entirely and soak
a nominal tax additionally upon each student.
There's no element of justice or defensible principle in the action; it's merely a question of expediency. It might even be asked, What-right has the
University to take $1,000 out of the S. A. fee collections as an assessment for overhead expense; is this
not a misappropriation of funds when the University
thereby repudiates its obligation of supylying the benefits of the activities without further charge?
It's a nice ethical mess. We're simply puddling
along, blundering frightfully, but doing the best possible under the circumstances. If some wizard will
suggest the solution nobody's going to snub him. The
only thing that seems immediately incumbent upon
the authorities is to apply the money which they have
derived from partially reopened accounts in the channels which will most recompense the student for his
ten-dollar outlay. Dean Berry has promised to pay
off after the first of February and we have no reason
to believe that he won't, considering that he has the
money.

The Secret Of Success

*

"College Coaches Oppose Proselyting, Pay to
Athletes," headline on short article in local paper
referring to a resolution passed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association at its recent Chicago
meeting.
Amazement seized us bodily. (There's vividness

for you.) What will happen to the grand old game
of football 'now, we remorsed. Only three men in
the group of 150 coaches, the article said, favored any
form of paying athletes. Of course all the others,
more willing to be transcendently noble than just plain
honest, just glared at the three worms (we imagine),
and shouted that they would not have it. No, they'd
lose their jobs rather than pay or proselyte an athlete.
But with the game of the gods tottering on the
brink of destruction; with the sport of manhood on
the verge of being immolated for the sake of a highsounding principle and a feeling of nobility which had
seized the coaches unawares and which now rather
frightened them, one of the old guard rushed in to
save the day. And who was that? None other than
the maestro of mentors, Fritz Crisler of Princeton,
who was doubtless motivated by remembering that if
he lost his job why, after all, you know, there are the
wife and kiddies.
He probably thumped the table; we don't know
because we weren't there and the writer of the article
omitted to say. He probably said, "Gentlemen, you're
right. The escutcheon of sports must not be sullied
by the bar sinister of professionalism !" The article
leaves us to the resources of our own imagination
there, too. But he did say that paying athletes openly
(italics our own) would ruin football.
There's diplomacy for you; there's consummately
skillful smoothing over of a bad situation. We imagine that all the coaches just looked relieved, nudged
each other, and said "Good old Fritz! Always says
the right thing at the right time. They'll never catch
old Fritz." And the reporter, anxious to do what was
right, gave Fritz the credit for having saved the day
for Coachdom.
Gee, ain't it wonderful!

Intercollegiate News
The feminine attendance at a certain professor's
Saturday morning sociology class at Lehigh was not
large enough to warrant the professor's annual discussion of the education of wOmen, but he did stop
to mention that Vassar was founded by a brewer who
was trying to prove that women really could be
educated.
* * *
One Protestant student at Lehigh was very much
embarrassed when he awoke one Sunday morning to
find himself in evening clothes at Catholic mass.
* * *
Rumor has it that at the University of Minnesota
one out of every 20 girls paints her toe nails.
* * *
At the University of Florida exactly thirty-nine
freshmen were promised the freshman class presidency
during the active campaigning of "rush week".
* * *
A questionnaire reveals that 298 of the class of
1937 came to Princeton for an education, 179 because of the University's name and reputation, and
70 for contacts and social advantages.
* * *

Enrollment at the University of Detroit shows
that 3,543 women and only 77 men attend the school—
what a school!
* * *
Something new in football—at Ohio State University there is a twelfth position on the football team.
The extra man is called the "humorist". He wears a
uniform at all practices and sits on the bench during
the games. His job is to keep the team in good humor and prevent them from getting nervous before
a big game.
* * *
Having been granted permission to smoke in
classes, co-eds at Washington College came to a psychology class sporting corn-cob pipes. The professor ordered that all windows be kept tightly closed.
In a short time the class fled.

DRIBBLERS VISIT EMMITSBURG
FOR LEAGUE OPENER TONIGHT
AFTER POOR NORTHERN SWING

Devitt Prep, Rider Are
Added To Mat
Schedule
Two teams, not encountered
heretofore by the Blue Jay wrestlers, have been added to this
year's schedule. Devitt Prep, of
Washington, D. C., will be met in
a home and home series. The
first meet is to take place in the
Capitol City this Saturday, January 13, and the return meet will
be held January 27 at Baltimore.
On February 17 Rider College
will act as host to the Jay grapplers.

N. S. L. CIRCULATES
PETITION PROPOSING
ABOLITION OF FEES
Expects To Present Paper
To Board Of Trustees
This Week
Not satisfied with the possible
results of THE NEWS-LETTER poll
in today's paper, an independent
group of students has been circulating a petition proposing the abolishment of compulsory activity fees.
The group is headed by the Hopkins branch of the National Student
League and consists of other students constituting a voluntary committee called the Committee Against
Compulsory Activity Fees.
A spokesman for the group stated
that more than five hundred students are expected to sign the petition. It will be presented to the
Board of Trustees during the week.
The petition asks for the abrogation of the ruling compelling all
students to pay the fees and presents two reasons for that request.
The first is that the ruling was established at the request of the students and that student sentiment at
the present time demands its rescinding. Secondly, the petition
claims, many student find it difficult
to pay the fees.

FACULTY
Dr. Hugh Hampton Young, professor of Urology at the Hopkins
and director of the Brady Urological Institute of the Johns Hopkins
Hospital, is one of the Americans
appearing for the first time in Great
Britain's list of the living great,
"Who's Who, 1934".
In 1893, the University of Virginia awarded him both his A.B.
and M.A. degrees. A year later, the
M.D. was granted him. Dr. Young
came to the Johns Hopkins Hospital in 1898 and has been connected
with the institution since that time.
Since the founding of the Journal
of Urology in 1917, Dr. Young has
been its editor. He is president of
the Societe Internationale d'Urologie, president of the American Association of Genito-Urinary Surgeons, and president of the American Urological Association. Dr.
Young has written over 300 papers
dealing with various phases of urology.

Liberal Club Hears Discussion
Of Recent Student Conference
Discussion of the recent National
Conference on Students in Politics
was the main subject at the meeting of the Liberal Club last Friday.
The National Conference, held in
Washington, December 29-31, was
an attempt to establish a foundation
for uniting the student movements
throughout the country on some
common basis. The gathering met
in the Chamber of Commerce building on the condition that it pass no
resolutions.
However, it became evident during the meetings that large majorities of the students present were
strongly opposed to the R. 0. T. C.
and other war activities, to race discrimination, and to retrenchment in
education, and the executive committee drew up a declaration to that
effect.

DOES NOT SPILL OUT
Good tobaccos... real good tobaccos...that's the reason
for Lucky Strike's fine, smooth quality. We use only
the center leaves of the finest Turkish and domestic tobacco plants. Not the top leaves—because those are underdeveloped. Not the bottom leaves—because those are inferior in quality. We use only the center leaves—because
these are the mildest leaves—fully ripe for perfect smoking. Only these choice tobaccos are used to make Luckies
—so round, so firm, so fully packed— and no loose ends
to spill out. That's why Luckies are always mild and
smooth. That's why always "Luckies please". And don't
forget—"It's toasted"—for throat protection—for finer taste.

Tuesday, January 9, 1934

Let's Dodge The Issue
Modestly boasting himself as no more than an
undergraduate, a correspondent in our letter column
today asks why additional charges are made when
the Student Activities Fee is guaranteed to entitle
students to all activity functions without further
charge. The query is interesting, not because of possessing any originality but because it is one which
numerous simple-hearted lads have advanced with
varying degrees of temerity.
We don't know of anybody on the campus who
pretends that the plan is fair. The whole matter,
briefly, is this: creditors not paid last semester because of the bank closing raised such a holler when
activities fees were collected this year that they had to
be paid before we could go on with anything else.
This took over half of our money. Assuming that
activities are necessary and that the students want
them (pity THE NEWS-LETTER if they don't), the only
way that any operations were possible at all was to
disregard the principle of the thing entirely and soak
a nominal tax additionally upon each student.
There's no element of justice or defensible principle in the action; it's merely a question of expediency. It might even be asked, What-right has the
University to take $1,000 out of the S. A. fee collections as an assessment for overhead expense; is this
not a misappropriation of funds when the University
thereby repudiates its obligation of supylying the benefits of the activities without further charge?
It's a nice ethical mess. We're simply puddling
along, blundering frightfully, but doing the best possible under the circumstances. If some wizard will
suggest the solution nobody's going to snub him. The
only thing that seems immediately incumbent upon
the authorities is to apply the money which they have
derived from partially reopened accounts in the channels which will most recompense the student for his
ten-dollar outlay. Dean Berry has promised to pay
off after the first of February and we have no reason
to believe that he won't, considering that he has the
money.

The Secret Of Success

*

"College Coaches Oppose Proselyting, Pay to
Athletes," headline on short article in local paper
referring to a resolution passed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association at its recent Chicago
meeting.
Amazement seized us bodily. (There's vividness

for you.) What will happen to the grand old game
of football 'now, we remorsed. Only three men in
the group of 150 coaches, the article said, favored any
form of paying athletes. Of course all the others,
more willing to be transcendently noble than just plain
honest, just glared at the three worms (we imagine),
and shouted that they would not have it. No, they'd
lose their jobs rather than pay or proselyte an athlete.
But with the game of the gods tottering on the
brink of destruction; with the sport of manhood on
the verge of being immolated for the sake of a highsounding principle and a feeling of nobility which had
seized the coaches unawares and which now rather
frightened them, one of the old guard rushed in to
save the day. And who was that? None other than
the maestro of mentors, Fritz Crisler of Princeton,
who was doubtless motivated by remembering that if
he lost his job why, after all, you know, there are the
wife and kiddies.
He probably thumped the table; we don't know
because we weren't there and the writer of the article
omitted to say. He probably said, "Gentlemen, you're
right. The escutcheon of sports must not be sullied
by the bar sinister of professionalism !" The article
leaves us to the resources of our own imagination
there, too. But he did say that paying athletes openly
(italics our own) would ruin football.
There's diplomacy for you; there's consummately
skillful smoothing over of a bad situation. We imagine that all the coaches just looked relieved, nudged
each other, and said "Good old Fritz! Always says
the right thing at the right time. They'll never catch
old Fritz." And the reporter, anxious to do what was
right, gave Fritz the credit for having saved the day
for Coachdom.
Gee, ain't it wonderful!

Intercollegiate News
The feminine attendance at a certain professor's
Saturday morning sociology class at Lehigh was not
large enough to warrant the professor's annual discussion of the education of wOmen, but he did stop
to mention that Vassar was founded by a brewer who
was trying to prove that women really could be
educated.
* * *
One Protestant student at Lehigh was very much
embarrassed when he awoke one Sunday morning to
find himself in evening clothes at Catholic mass.
* * *
Rumor has it that at the University of Minnesota
one out of every 20 girls paints her toe nails.
* * *
At the University of Florida exactly thirty-nine
freshmen were promised the freshman class presidency
during the active campaigning of "rush week".
* * *
A questionnaire reveals that 298 of the class of
1937 came to Princeton for an education, 179 because of the University's name and reputation, and
70 for contacts and social advantages.
* * *

Enrollment at the University of Detroit shows
that 3,543 women and only 77 men attend the school—
what a school!
* * *
Something new in football—at Ohio State University there is a twelfth position on the football team.
The extra man is called the "humorist". He wears a
uniform at all practices and sits on the bench during
the games. His job is to keep the team in good humor and prevent them from getting nervous before
a big game.
* * *
Having been granted permission to smoke in
classes, co-eds at Washington College came to a psychology class sporting corn-cob pipes. The professor ordered that all windows be kept tightly closed.
In a short time the class fled.

Capitol City this Saturday, January 13, and the return meet will
be held January 27 at Baltimore.
On February 17 Rider College
will act as host to the Jay grapplers.

N. S. L. CIRCULATES
PETITION PROPOSING
ABOLITION OF FEES
Expects To Present Paper
To Board Of Trustees
This Week
Not satisfied with the possible
results of THE NEWS-LETTER poll
in today's paper, an independent
group of students has been circulating a petition proposing the abolishment of compulsory activity fees.
The group is headed by the Hopkins branch of the National Student
League and consists of other students constituting a voluntary committee called the Committee Against
Compulsory Activity Fees.
A spokesman for the group stated
that more than five hundred students are expected to sign the petition. It will be presented to the
Board of Trustees during the week.
The petition asks for the abrogation of the ruling compelling all
students to pay the fees and presents two reasons for that request.
The first is that the ruling was established at the request of the students and that student sentiment at
the present time demands its rescinding. Secondly, the petition
claims, many student find it difficult
to pay the fees.

FACULTY
Dr. Hugh Hampton Young, professor of Urology at the Hopkins
and director of the Brady Urological Institute of the Johns Hopkins
Hospital, is one of the Americans
appearing for the first time in Great
Britain's list of the living great,
"Who's Who, 1934".
In 1893, the University of Virginia awarded him both his A.B.
and M.A. degrees. A year later, the
M.D. was granted him. Dr. Young
came to the Johns Hopkins Hospital in 1898 and has been connected
with the institution since that time.
Since the founding of the Journal
of Urology in 1917, Dr. Young has
been its editor. He is president of
the Societe Internationale d'Urologie, president of the American Association of Genito-Urinary Surgeons, and president of the American Urological Association. Dr.
Young has written over 300 papers
dealing with various phases of urology.

Liberal Club Hears Discussion
Of Recent Student Conference
Discussion of the recent National
Conference on Students in Politics
was the main subject at the meeting of the Liberal Club last Friday.
The National Conference, held in
Washington, December 29-31, was
an attempt to establish a foundation
for uniting the student movements
throughout the country on some
common basis. The gathering met
in the Chamber of Commerce building on the condition that it pass no
resolutions.
However, it became evident during the meetings that large majorities of the students present were
strongly opposed to the R. 0. T. C.
and other war activities, to race discrimination, and to retrenchment in
education, and the executive committee drew up a declaration to that
effect.
